tit.cmt: 本因坊は姓ではありませんので、大文字化していません。

sen.j: 本因坊 秀哉（ほんいんぼう しゅうさい、1874年 6月24日- 1940年1月18日）は、明治から昭和にかけての囲碁の棋士 (囲碁)。
sen.e: Honinbo (Holder of the Honinbo Title for the strongest player of the board game of go) Shusai (June 24, 1874 - January 18, 1940) was a go (the board game of go, hereinafter referred to as go) player who lived from the Meiji period through to the Showa period.

Honinbo (Holder of the Honinbo Title for the strongest player of the board game of go) Shusai (June 24, 1874 - January 18, 1940) was a go (the board game of go, hereinafter referred to as go) player who lived from the Meiji period through to the Showa period.

Honinbo (Holder of the Honinbo Title for the strongest player of the board game of go) Shusai (June 24, 1874 - January 18, 1940) was a go (the board game of go, hereinafter referred to as go) player who lived from the Meiji period through to the Showa period.

sen.j: 東京都出身。
sen.e: Shusai was born in Tokyo.
He was born in Tokyo.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: He was born in Tokyo.

sen.j: 本名は田村保寿（やすひさ）。
sen.e: Shusai was born Yasuhisa (also known as Hoju) TAMURA.
He was born Yasuhisa (also known as Hoju) TAMURA.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: His name was Yasuhisa (also known as Hoju) TAMURA.

sen.j: 名人 (囲碁)。
sen.e: Shusai was a master (which is called Meijin in Japanese) of go.
He was a master (which is called Meijin in Japanese) of go.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: He was a master (which is called Meijin in Japanese) of go.

sen.j: 家元本因坊の21世で、終身名人制の最後の名人。
sen.e: Shusai was the 21st Iemoto (grand master) of the go school of Honinbo, being the last Permanent Meijin (Meijin-for-life).
He was the 21st Iemoto (grand master) of the go school of Honinbo, being the last Permanent Meijin (Meijin-for-life).
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: He was the 21st Iemoto (grand master) of the go school of Honinbo, being the last Permanent Meijin (Meijin-for-life).

sen.j: 法名は日温。
sen.e: Shusai's homyo (Buddhist priest's name or posthumous Buddhist name) was Nichion.
His homyo (Buddhist priest's name or posthumous Buddhist name) was Nichion.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: His homyo (Buddhist priest's name or posthumous Buddhist name) was Nichion.

sen.j: 引退後に本因坊の名跡を日本棋院に譲渡し、選手権制の本因坊戦創設に導いた。
sen.e: After retirement, Shusai transferred the title of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in (literally, the Japanese Go Association), which led to the foundation of Honinbo title match.
After retirement, he transferred the title of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in (literally, the Japanese Go Association), which led to the foundation of Honinbo title match.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: After retirement, he transferred the title of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in (literally, the Japanese Go Association), which led to the foundation of Honinbo title match.

sen.j: 棋風は力戦に強く、「序盤に策あり」と言われた。
sen.e: Shosai's style was characterized by dominating a riki-sen match (also called chikara-go, referring to a match full of nonstandard moves in the game of go, or rather scuffled match in which players' abilities are tested), people praised him by describing, "Shusai has a plan in an opening game."

His style was characterized by dominating a riki-sen match (also called chikara-go, referring to a match full of nonstandard moves in the game of go, or rather scuffled match in which players' abilities are tested), people praised him by describing, "Shusai has a plan in an opening game."
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: His style was characterized by dominating a riki-sen match (also called chikara-go, referring to a match full of nonstandard moves in the game of go, or rather scuffled match in which players' abilities are tested), people praised him by describing, "Shusai has a plan in an opening game."

sen.j: 2008年囲碁殿堂入り。
sen.e: Shusai was inducted into the Go Hall of Fame in 2008.
He was inducted into the Go Hall of Fame in 2008.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: He was inducted into the Go Hall of Fame in 2008.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 修行時代
sen.e: Training Days
Training Days
Training Days

sen.j: 1874年（明治7年）6月24日、東京に生まれる。
sen.e: Yasuhisa TAMURA (the future Honinbo Shusai) was born in Tokyo on June 24, 1874.
Yasuhisa TAMURA (the future Honinbo Shusai) was born in Tokyo on June 24, 1874.
Yasuhisa TAMURA (the future Honinbo Shusai) was born in Tokyo on June 24, 1874.

sen.j: 父は内務省 (日本)勤務の田村保永、伯父は貴族院 (日本)議員でシーメンス事件での弾劾演説で知られる村田保。
sen.e: Yasuhisa's father was Yasunaga TAMURA who worked at the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs, and his uncle (parent's older brother) was Tamotsu MURATA who was a senator of the House of Lords and known for his impeachment address against Yamamoto's Cabinet which was allegedly involved in the Siemens scandal.

Yasuhisa's father was Yasunaga TAMURA who worked at the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs, and his uncle (parent's older brother) was Tamotsu MURATA who was a senator of the House of Lords and known for his impeachment address against Yamamoto's Cabinet which was allegedly involved in the Siemens scandal.

Yasuhisa's father was Yasunaga TAMURA who worked at the prewar Ministry of Home Affairs, and his uncle (parent's older brother) was Tamotsu MURATA who was a senator of the House of Lords and known for his impeachment address against Yamamoto's Cabinet which was allegedly involved in the Siemens scandal.

sen.j: 保寿は父の趣味の影響で囲碁を覚えた。
sen.e: Yasuhisa's father, whose hobby was playing go, inspired Yasuhisa to learn go.
Yasuhisa's father, whose hobby was playing go, inspired Yasuhisa to learn go.
Yasuhisa's father, whose hobby was playing go, inspired Yasuhisa to learn go.

sen.j: 1885年11歳のとき、方円社に入塾。
sen.e: In 1885, when Yasuhisa was 11, he entered the Hoensha (a study group formed by top professional go players during the Meiji period).
In 1885, when Yasuhisa was 11, he entered the Hoensha (a study group formed by top professional go players during the Meiji period).
In 1885, when Yasuhisa was 11, he entered the Hoensha (a study group formed by top professional go players during the Meiji period).

sen.j: 当時の住み込みの塾生は、塾頭の石井千治、道家富太、杉岡榮治郎、田村保寿の四人だった。
sen.e: At that time when Yasuhisa studied at the Hoensha, there were only four live-in disciples including Senji ISHII who was the school manager, Tomita DOKE, Eijiro SUGIOKA and Yasuhisa TAMURA.
When Yasuhisa studied at the Hoensha, there were only four live-in disciples including Senji ISHII who was the school manager, Tomita DOKE, Eijiro SUGIOKA and Yasuhisa TAMURA.
sen.cmt: 意味が重複するので、at that timeを削除しました。
sen.e: When Yasuhisa studied at the Hoensha, there were only four live-in disciples including Senji ISHII who was the school manager, Tomita DOKE, Eijiro SUGIOKA and Yasuhisa TAMURA.

sen.j: 田村は、石井千治、杉岡榮治郎とともに方円社の三小僧と呼ばれた。
sen.e: Yasuhisa TAMURA, Senji ISHII and Eijiro SUGIOKA, were collectively called the Three Boys of the Hoensha ('Hoensha no San-kozo' in Japanese).
Yasuhisa TAMURA, Senji ISHII and Eijiro SUGIOKA, were collectively called the Three Boys of the Hoensha ('Hoensha no San-kozo' in Japanese).
Yasuhisa TAMURA, Senji ISHII and Eijiro SUGIOKA, were collectively called the Three Boys of the Hoensha ('Hoensha no San-kozo' in Japanese).

sen.j: 1891年（明治24年）、11月、方円社を除名され、一時期囲碁から離れる。
sen.e: In November, 1891, Yasuhisa was expelled from the Hoensha, thereafter staying away from go for a while.
In November 1891, Yasuhisa was expelled from the Hoensha, thereafter staying away from go for a while.
sen.cmt: 不要な句読点を削除しました。
sen.e: In November 1891, Yasuhisa was expelled from the Hoensha, thereafter staying away from go for a while.

sen.j: 19歳の時に金玉均を介して19世本因坊秀栄門下に入門。
sen.e: At the age of 19, Yasuhisa was invited by Gyokukin KIN (KIM Ok-gyun) to joining the Honinbo school under the 19th Iemoto Honinbo Shuei, and so he did.
At the age of 19, Yasuhisa joined the Honinbo school under the 19th Iemoto Honinbo Shuei, having been invited by Gyokukin KIN (KIM Ok-gyun).
sen.cmt: 表現が冗長的だったので簡潔にしました。
sen.e: At the age of 19, Yasuhisa joined the Honinbo school under the 19th Iemoto Honinbo Shuei, having been invited by Gyokukin KIN (KIM Ok-gyun).

sen.j: 秀栄門下でも強さを発揮し、当時他の棋士達をことごとく先二以下に打ち込んでいた秀栄に唯一定先を保ち、本因坊継承の最有力候補と見られていた。
sen.e: As a disciple of Shuei, Tamura exerted the usual strength such that he alone could keep taking Black to move first throughout a game (one-stone-handicap game called josen) with Master Shuei who otherwise kept gaining the upper hand with the other disciples by playing a handicap game called sen-ni (i.e. for two games out of three, the lower-rank player is allowed to take Black and for the last one game he or she plays a two-stone-handicap game), and Tamura was therefore viewed as the most successful candidate for the next Honinbo.
sen.cmt: 「先二」というのは、「下位者が3局のうち2局を先手、1局を2子番（置碁）とする。」という先二先に相当すると理解しました。
sen.e: As a disciple of Shuei, Tamura exerted the usual strength such that he alone could keep taking Black to move first throughout a game (one-stone-handicap game called josen) with Master Shuei who otherwise kept gaining the upper hand with the other disciples by playing a handicap game called sen-ni (i.e. for two games out of three, the lower-rank player is allowed to take Black and for the last one game he or she plays a two-stone-handicap game), and Tamura was therefore viewed as the most successful candidate for the next Honinbo.

As a disciple of Shuei, Tamura exerted the usual strength such that he alone could keep taking Black to move first throughout a game (one-stone-handicap game called josen) with Master Shuei who otherwise kept gaining the upper hand with the other disciples by playing a handicap game called sen-ni (i.e. for two games out of three, the lower-rank player is allowed to take Black and for the last one game he or she plays a two-stone-handicap game), and Tamura was therefore viewed as the most successful candidate for the next Honinbo.

sen.j: しかし、秀栄本人は田村の事を嫌い、後を継がせる事に消極的で秀栄が寝込む様になってからは面会も許されなくなった。
sen.e: However, Master Shuei who personally disliked Tamura hesitated to let Tamura succeed his title, and after he became ill in bed, Tamura was never permitted to visit him.
However, Master Shuei who personally disliked Tamura hesitated to let Tamura succeed his title, and after he became ill in bed, Tamura was never permitted to visit him.
However, Master Shuei who personally disliked Tamura hesitated to let Tamura succeed his title, and after he became ill in bed, Tamura was never permitted to visit him.

sen.j: 秀栄は雁金準一の実力が田村に及ばないことを認めながら、田村でなく雁金を後継者に望んでいたふしがある。
sen.e: Knowing that Junichi KARIGANE did not come up to Tamura's shoulder, Shuei still seemed to hope that Juinchi succeed him.
Knowing that Junichi KARIGANE did not come up to Tamura's shoulder, Shuei still seemed to hope that Juinchi succeed him.
Knowing that Junichi KARIGANE did not come up to Tamura's shoulder, Shuei still seemed to hope that Juinchi succeed him.

sen.j: 田村の性格は極めて我が強く、また金銭にうるさい所があり、そういった所が秀栄に嫌われた要因であろうと言われている。
sen.e: It is said that wayward and penny-pinching Yasuhisa was hated by Shuei due to his such character.
sen.cmt: ｢金銭にうるさい」の意味は、「金に細かい（けちな）」と解釈しました。
sen.e: It is said that wayward and penny-pinching Yasuhisa was hated by Shuei due to his such character.
It is said that wayward and penny-pinching Yasuhisa was hated by Shuei due to his such character.

sen.j: 本因坊秀哉時代
sen.e: Days as Honinbo Shusai
Days as Honinbo Shusai
Days as Honinbo Shusai

sen.j: 1907年、田村は本因坊継承の運動を盛んに行っていたものの結局秀栄は後継を決めないままに死去。
sen.e: In 1907, despite Tamura's continuous appeal for the right to succeed the title of Honinbo, Shuei died without designating his successor.
In 1907, despite Tamura's continuous appeal for the right to succeed the title of Honinbo, Shuei died without designating his successor.
In 1907, despite Tamura's continuous appeal for the right to succeed the title of Honinbo, Shuei died without designating his successor.

sen.j: 後継者問題で本因坊家内は大いにもめ、田村は孤立無援に追い込まれた。
sen.e: This successor problem caused much trouble inside the school of Honinbo, and Tamura was left holding on his own.
This successor problem caused much trouble inside the school of Honinbo, and Tamura was left holding on his own.
This successor problem caused much trouble inside the school of Honinbo, and Tamura was left holding on his own.

sen.j: この事態を収めたのは、16世本因坊であり、秀栄の弟の本因坊秀元であった。
sen.e: The disputes over the successor were resolved by the 16th Honinbo named Shugen who was a younger brother of Shuei.
The disputes over the successor were resolved by the 16th Honinbo named Shugen who was a younger brother of Shuei.
The disputes over the successor were resolved by the 16th Honinbo named Shugen who was a younger brother of Shuei.

sen.j: 秀元は一旦20世本因坊に就き、一年後田村に本因坊を継がせることでこの事態を収拾した。
sen.e: Shugen suggested that he took over the title of the 20th Honinbo temporarily and let Tamura succeed him one year later, thereby resolving the disputes.
Shugen suggested that he took over the title of the 20th Honinbo temporarily and let Tamura succeed him one year later, thereby resolving the disputes.
Shugen suggested that he took over the title of the 20th Honinbo temporarily and let Tamura succeed him one year later, thereby resolving the disputes.

sen.j: 1908年、34歳で21世本因坊秀哉となる。
sen.e: In 1908, at the age of 34, Tamura became the 21st Honinbo Shusai.
In 1908, at the age of 34, Tamura became the 21st Honinbo Shusai.
In 1908, at the age of 34, Tamura became the 21st Honinbo Shusai.

sen.j: その後、周りに自分の実力を見せ付けるように他の一流棋士達を先二以下に打ち込む。
sen.e: Once becoming the Honinbo, Shusai proved the difference by dominating the other top-ranked professional go players who could only play a handicap game of at least sen-ni with Shusai.
Once becoming the Honinbo, Shusai proved the difference by dominating the other top-ranked professional go players who could only play a handicap game of at least sen-ni with Shusai.
Once becoming the Honinbo, Shusai proved the difference by dominating the other top-ranked professional go players who could only play a handicap game of at least sen-ni with Shusai.

sen.j: 1914年、41歳の時に名人 (囲碁)位就位。
sen.e: In 1914, at the age of 41, Shusai was conferred the title of Meijin (the strongest go player and the Master of go).
In 1914, at the age of 41, he was conferred the title of Meijin (the strongest go player and the Master of go).
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: In 1914, at the age of 41, he was conferred the title of Meijin (the strongest go player and the Master of go).

sen.j: 名実ともに棋界第一人者になる。
sen.e: Thus, Shusai came out on top of all the professional go players in Japan both in name and reality.
Thus, he came out on top of all the professional go players in Japan both in name and reality.
sen.cmt: 文脈で判断可能だと思われるので、代名詞に置き換えました。
sen.e: Thus, he came out on top of all the professional go players in Japan both in name and reality.

sen.j: 1926年、日本棋院対棋正社の対抗戦で、雁金準一と対決。
sen.e: In 1926, at a tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha, Shusai played a match against Junichi KARIGANE.
In 1926, at a tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha, Shusai played a match against Junichi KARIGANE.
In 1926, at a tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha, Shusai played a match against Junichi KARIGANE.

sen.j: 石取りの名局と謳われたスリリングなねじり合いの末に勝利し、不敗の名人の名を高めることとなった。
sen.e: As a result of that renowned go match full of thrilling twists and turns, Shusai defeated Junichi, thereby achieving distinction as the invincible Meijin.
As a result of that renowned go match full of thrilling twists and turns, Shusai defeated Junichi, thereby achieving distinction as the invincible Meijin.
As a result of that renowned go match full of thrilling twists and turns, Shusai defeated Junichi, thereby achieving distinction as the invincible Meijin.

sen.j: 1933年～1934年、読売新聞主催の「日本囲碁選手権手合」に優勝した呉清源五段と向先で対戦、2目勝ちを収める（後述）。
sen.e: From 1933 to 1934 Shusai played a match against Seigen GO who was a holder of fifth dan (rank) and had won the "Japan Go Championship" hosted by The Yomiuri Shimbun, and in that match between Shusai and Seigen a handicap called Mukai-sen (or Muko-sen) was applied and Seigen therefore took Black throughout the match, resulting in Shusai's victory by 2 points (to be hereinafter described).
sen.cmt: 「向先」の読みとルールがよく分かりません。「向先はハンディキャップの一種であり、相手が黒のみ」ということだけ分かりましたのでそのように訳出しております。参考：http://ameblo.jp/gogoigoigo/entry-10460954786.html
sen.e: From 1933 to 1934 Shusai played a match against Seigen GO who was a holder of fifth dan (rank) and had won the "Japan Go Championship" hosted by The Yomiuri Shimbun, and in that match between Shusai and Seigen a handicap called Mukai-sen (or Muko-sen) was applied and Seigen therefore took Black throughout the match, resulting in Shusai's victory by 2 points (to be hereinafter described).

From 1933 to 1934 Shusai played a match against Seigen GO who was a holder of fifth dan (rank) and had won the "Japan Go Championship" hosted by The Yomiuri Shimbun, and in that match between Shusai and Seigen a handicap called Mukai-sen (or Muko-sen) was applied and Seigen therefore took Black throughout the match, resulting in Shusai's victory by 2 points (to be hereinafter described).

sen.j: 1936年、秀哉は日本棋院に本因坊の名跡を譲渡。
sen.e: In 1936, Shusai assigned and transferred the professional name of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in.
In 1936, Shusai assigned and transferred the professional name of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in.
In 1936, Shusai assigned and transferred the professional name of Honinbo to the Nihon Ki-in.

sen.j: 世襲制ではなく選手権戦によって本因坊を決める本因坊戦が誕生する。
sen.e: This led to the foundation of the Honinbo title match which enabled the successor of Honinbo to be determined not hereditarily but by the championship match.
This led to the foundation of the Honinbo title match which enabled the successor of Honinbo to be determined not hereditarily but by the championship match.
This led to the foundation of the Honinbo title match which enabled the successor of Honinbo to be determined not hereditarily but by the championship match.

sen.j: 秀哉は後継者として愛弟子の小岸壮二を考えていたといわれるが、意に反し小岸は夭折した。
sen.e: Shusai reportedly considered Soji KOGISHI (also read OGISHI) a strong favorite to his successor, but despite the intension of Shusai Kogishi died young.
Shusai reportedly considered making Soji KOGISHI (also read OGISHI), who was Shusai's strong favorite disciple, his successor, but unfortunately Shusai Kogishi died young.
sen.cmt: 訳文がわかりにくかったため表現を訂正しました。また「意に反して」の部分はtrans1は誤訳だと思い、「intention of」や「against～」などの訳も考えましたが、文脈に合わないため、unfortunatelyという表現にしました。
sen.e: Shusai reportedly considered making Soji KOGISHI (also read OGISHI), who was Shusai's strong favorite disciple, his successor, but unfortunately Shusai Kogishi died young.

sen.j: 次には前田陳爾に望みを託したが、木谷実、呉清源の活躍の前にその夢も消えた。
sen.e: After Kogishi's death, Shusai concentrated his hopes on Nobuaki MAEDA, but fine performances by Minoru KITANI and Seigen GO stopped him from doing so.
After Kogishi's death, Shusai concentrated his hopes on Nobuaki MAEDA, but fine performances by Minoru KITANI and Seigen GO stopped him from doing so.
After Kogishi's death, Shusai concentrated his hopes on Nobuaki MAEDA, but fine performances by Minoru KITANI and Seigen GO stopped him from doing so.

sen.j: 秀哉には自身の経験から実力第一位のものに本因坊の名を継がせたいという強い思いがあり、本因坊位の世襲制廃止に踏み切ったものと言われる。
sen.e: From his own bitter experience, Shusai strongly wished that the strongest be designated as the successor of Honinbo, and that was reportedly the reason he decided to abolish Honinbo's hereditary succession system.
From his own bitter experience, Shusai strongly wished to give the Honinbo Title to the strongest, so presumably, he decided to abolish Honinbo's hereditary succession system.
sen.cmt: 訳文の意味が不明だったので、全体的に表現を修正しました。
sen.e: From his own bitter experience, Shusai strongly wished to give the Honinbo Title to the strongest, so presumably, he decided to abolish Honinbo's hereditary succession system.

sen.j: 1938年、秀哉は引退を決意。
sen.e: In 1938 Shusai decided to retire.
In 1938 Shusai decided to retire.
In 1938 Shusai decided to retire.

sen.j: 木谷実との歴史に残る引退碁を打つ（後述）。
sen.e: Shusai played his last go match before retirement against Minoru KITANI, and the match became history (to be discussed later).
Shusai played his last go match before retirement against Minoru KITANI, and the match became history (to be discussed later).
Shusai played his last go match before retirement against Minoru KITANI, and the match became history (to be discussed later).

sen.j: 1940年1月18日、実力制初代本因坊の決定を見ることなく死去。
sen.e: On January 18, 1940, Shusai died without knowing who was to win the first Honinbo by championship.
On January 18, 1940, Shusai died without knowing who was to win the first Honinbo by championship.
On January 18, 1940, Shusai died without knowing who was to win the first Honinbo by championship.

sen.j: 歴代本因坊が眠る本妙寺に葬られた。
sen.e: Shusai's body was buried at the graveyard of Honmyo-ji Temple, where successive Honinbos had been resting in peace.
Shusai's body was buried at the graveyard of Honmyo-ji Temple, where successive Honinbos had been resting in peace.
Shusai's body was buried at the graveyard of Honmyo-ji Temple, where successive Honinbos had been resting in peace.

sen.j: 代表局
sen.e: Major Matches
Major Matches
Major Matches

sen.j: 院社対抗戦
sen.e: A Tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha
A Tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha
A Tournament held between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha

sen.j: 1926年、日本棋院対棋正社の全面対抗戦の初戦において、雁金準一との主将同士の決戦に臨んだ。
sen.e: In 1926, a full-scale tournament between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha took place, and in the first match Shusai fought a decisive battle with Junichi KARIGANE, which was the battle between captains of the two teams.

In 1926, a full-scale tournament between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha took place, and in the first match Shusai fought a decisive battle with Junichi KARIGANE, which was the battle between captains of the two teams.

In 1926, a full-scale tournament between the Nihon Ki-in and the Kiseisha took place, and in the first match Shusai fought a decisive battle with Junichi KARIGANE, which was the battle between captains of the two teams.

sen.j: 下辺の白模様に突入した雁金の黒石を、秀哉が強引に取りに行ったことから大乱戦となり、満天下を沸かせるスリリングな一戦となった。
sen.e: Karigane's black stone which got in a lower white framework ('moyo' in Japanese) was taken high-handedly by Shusai, which made the match scuffled, thrilling people all over the world.
Karigane's black stone which got in a lower white framework ('moyo' in Japanese) was taken high-handedly by Shusai, which made the match scuffled, thrilling people all over the world.
Karigane's black stone which got in a lower white framework ('moyo' in Japanese) was taken high-handedly by Shusai, which made the match scuffled, thrilling people all over the world.

sen.j: 主催の読売新聞は各地で大盤を用いて速報し、観戦記に菊池寛、河東碧梧桐など有名文士を配して宣伝に努め、部数を一挙に3倍に伸ばしたといわれる。
sen.e: The Yomiuri Shimbun which hosted the tournament brought a special bulletin showing a large go board to replicate the game to various locations, and advertised by including reviews of the match written by Kan KIKUCHI and Hekigoto KAWAHIGASHI, leading men of letters, thereby reportedly tripling the number of copy of the paper at once.
sen.cmt: 大盤（解説用のスチール製大型ゲームボード）http://d.hatena.ne.jp/keyword/%C2%E7%C8%D7%B2%F2%C0%E2
sen.e: The Yomiuri Shimbun which hosted the tournament brought a special bulletin showing a large go board to replicate the game to various locations, and advertised by including reviews of the match written by Kan KIKUCHI and Hekigoto KAWAHIGASHI, leading men of letters, thereby reportedly tripling the number of copy of the paper at once.

The Yomiuri Shimbun which hosted the tournament brought a special bulletin showing a large go board to replicate the game to various locations, and advertised by including reviews of the match written by Kan KIKUCHI and Hekigoto KAWAHIGASHI, leading men of letters, thereby reportedly tripling the number of copy of the paper at once.
42 tsugu (37) 44 tsugu (35), where the term tsugu means that a stone is placed by a player to complement a weak link of the chained stones.
42 tsugu (37) 44 tsugu (35), where the term tsugu means that a stone is placed by a player to complement a weak link of the chained stones.
42 tsugu (37) 44 tsugu (35), where the term tsugu means that a stone is placed by a player to complement a weak link of the chained stones.

sen.j: 下辺黒1とカドに打ち込んだところから乱戦が開始された。
sen.e: An invasion ('uchikomi' in Japanese) to the lower Black 1 with a diagonal move ('kado' in Japanese) triggered the scuffle.
sen.cmt: 原文「打ち込み（囲碁）ところから」はリンク先表示であり、正しくは「打ち込んだところから」とwikiサイトにありますので、そのように修正のうえ訳出しました。http://ja.wikipedia.org/wiki/本因坊秀哉 「カド」＝角＝diagonal move from an enemy stoneと理解しました。
sen.e: An invasion ('uchikomi' in Japanese) to the lower Black 1 with a diagonal move ('kado' in Japanese) triggered the scuffle.
An invasion ('uchikomi' in Japanese) to the lower Black 1 which was the urgent point ('kado' in Japanese) triggered the scuffle.
sen.cmt: カドとは「急所」のことになるようですので、修正しました。

sen.j: 秀哉は黒の眼を奪うが、雁金も包囲網の薄みをついて反撃、まれに見るねじり合いとなった。
sen.e: Shusai captured Black's eye, which, however, was responded by Karigane's counter-attacking move toward a weak link of White's encirclement, resulting in rare twists and turns.
Shusai captured Black's eye, which, however, was responded by Karigane's counter-attacking move toward a weak link of White's encirclement, resulting in a rare game with full of twists and turns.
Shusai captured Black's eye, which, however, was countered by Karigane's counter-attacking move toward a weak link of White's encirclement, resulting in a rare game full of twists and turns.

sen.j: 秀哉はここで発生したコウをきっかけに勝勢を確立、最後は雁金の時間切れ負けとなった。
sen.e: A ko (repetision of the same pattern of offence and defense) appeared there led Shusai to making a situation advantageous, thus ending the game when Karigane ran out of time.
A ko (repetision of the same pattern of offence and defense) appeared there led Shusai to making a situation advantageous, thus ending the game when Karigane ran out of time.
A ko (repetision of the same pattern of offence and defense) appeared there led Shusai to making a situation advantageous, thus ending the game when Karigane ran out of time.

sen.j: 呉清源との勝負碁
sen.e: Go Game with Seigen GO
Go Game with Seigen GO
Go Game with Seigen GO

sen.j: 1933年、呉清源は16人のトーナメントを勝ち抜いて「日本囲碁選手権手合」に優勝。
sen.e: In 1933, Seigen GO defeated 16 opponents at a tournament called "Japan Go Championship," winning the victory.
In 1933, Seigen GO defeated 16 opponents at a tournament called "Japan Go Championship" and won the victory.
sen.cmt: わかりにくい表現を修正しました。
sen.e: In 1933, Seigen GO defeated 16 opponents at a tournament called "Japan Go Championship" and won the victory.

sen.j: 第一人者本因坊秀哉と先番で対戦することとなる。
sen.e: Seigen fought with the leading professional go player Shusai by playing Black in every game ('senban' in Japanese).
Seigen fought with the leading professional go player Shusai by playing Black in every game ('senban' in Japanese).
Seigen fought with the leading professional go player Shusai by playing Black in every game ('senban' in Japanese).

sen.j: 時に秀哉59歳、呉20歳であった。
sen.e: Shusai was 59, while Seigen was 20 then.
sen.cmt: 呉と碁の区別が英文では難しい（ややこしい）為、呉は清源で読み替えています。
sen.e: Shusai was 59, while Seigen was 20 then.
Shusai was 59, while Seigen was 20 then.

sen.j: 持ち時間は各24時間、13回の打ち掛けをはさんで1934年1月29日に終了。
sen.e: 24 hours were allotted to each player, and the game was adjourned ('uchikake' in Japanese) 13 times before eventually reaching the end on January 29, 1934.
24 hours were allotted to each player, and the game was adjourned ('uchikake' in Japanese) 13 times before eventually reaching the end on January 29, 1934.
24 hours were allotted to each player, and the game was adjourned ('uchikake' in Japanese) 13 times before eventually reaching the end on January 29, 1934.

sen.j: 当初は単なる指導碁程度の趣であったが、読売新聞の大宣伝により次第に日本対中国、旧権威対新勢力の大勝負へと事態はヒートアップしていった。
sen.e: At the beginning the game looked like a mere go lesson, but The Yomiuri Shimbun's advertising campaign gradually turned the game to being viewed with political overtone such as Japan versus China or old authority versus new force, making the competition heating up.

At the beginning the game looked like a mere go lesson, but The Yomiuri Shimbun's advertising campaign gradually turned the game to being viewed with political overtone such as Japan versus China or old authority versus new force, making the competition heating up.

At the beginning the game looked like a mere go lesson, but The Yomiuri Shimbun's advertising campaign gradually turned the game to being viewed with political overtone such as Japan versus China or old authority versus new force, making the competition heating up.

sen.j: 10月16日に東京・京橋の鍛冶橋旅館にて対局開始。
sen.e: On October 16, the game between Shusai and Seigen began at Kajibashi-ryokan Japanese-style Inn in Kyobashi, Tokyo.
On October 16, the game between Shusai and Seigen began at Kajibashi-ryokan Japanese-style Inn in Kyobashi, Tokyo.
On October 16, the game between Shusai and Seigen began at Kajibashi-ryokan Japanese-style Inn in Kyobashi, Tokyo.

sen.j: 日本中の注目が集まる中、呉は第一着に本因坊家の禁手とされる三々打ち。
sen.e: Attracting the national attention, Seigen made his first move which was the san-san-uchi (literally, placing a stone at a 3-3 point) that the Honinbo school prohibited.
Attracting the national attention, Seigen made his first move which was the san-san-uchi (literally, placing a stone at a 3-3 point) that the Honinbo school prohibited.
Attracting the national attention, Seigen made his first move which was the san-san-uchi (literally, placing a stone at a 3-3 point) that the Honinbo school prohibited.

sen.j: 3手目に星 (囲碁)、5手目に天元という大胆な布石を披露し、満天下を沸かせた（新布石の項参照）。
sen.e: Seigen further demonstrated the adventurous opening portion of a game ('fuseki' in Japanese) such as the hoshi (star) at the third move and the tengen (center point or the origin of heaven) at the fifth move, exciting the audience across the country (see an article on the shinfuseki [the new opening strategy] below).

Seigen further demonstrated the adventurous opening portion of a game ('fuseki' in Japanese) such as the hoshi (star) at the third move and the tengen (center point or the origin of heaven) at the fifth move, exciting the audience across the country (see an article on the shinfuseki [the new opening strategy] below).

Seigen further demonstrated the adventurous opening portion of a game ('fuseki' in Japanese) such as the hoshi (star) at the third move and the tengen (center point or the origin of heaven) at the fifth move, exciting the audience across the country (see an article on the shinfuseki [the new opening strategy] below).

sen.j: 159手目まで進行した後、13回目の打ち継ぎ開始直後に、秀哉は呉の黒地に強襲をかける歴史的妙手を放つ。
sen.e: After advancing to the 159th move, and upon resuming the game after the 13th adjournment, Shusai made the historic move of excellence ('myoshu' in Japanese) to storm Seigen's black territory.
After advancing to the 159th move, and upon resuming the game after the 13th adjournment, Shusai made the historic move of excellence ('myoshu' in Japanese) to storm Seigen's black territory.
After advancing to the 159th move, and upon resuming the game after the 13th adjournment, Shusai made the historic move of excellence ('myoshu' in Japanese) to storm Seigen's black territory.

sen.j: 呉も「受けの妙手」と呼ばれたツケで応えて崩壊を免れるが、この攻防の間に秀哉は右方で黒5子を捕獲し、優勢を決定づけた。
sen.e: Seigen, on the other hand, responded by making the contact move ('tsuke' in Japanese) named "Uke no myoshu" (literally, excellent move in response), so that he avoided disruption of his territory, but Shusai captured 5 black stones in the right side as a result of such offence and defense, getting an advantage.

Seigen, on the other hand, responded by making the contact move ('tsuke' in Japanese) named "Uke no myoshu" (literally, excellent move in response), so that he avoided disruption of his territory, but Shusai captured 5 black stones in the right side as a result of such offence and defense, getting an advantage.

Seigen, on the other hand, responded by making the contact move ('tsuke' in Japanese) named "Uke no myoshu" (literally, excellent move in response), so that he avoided disruption of his territory, but Shusai captured 5 black stones in the right side as a result of such offence and defense, getting an advantage.

sen.j: 秀哉160手目の妙手（白1）と、受けの妙手161手目ツケ（黒2）
sen.e: Shusai's myoshu (White 1) made at the 160th move and the tsuke (Black 2) known as the "Uke no myoshu" made at the 161st move.
Shusai's myoshu (White 1) made at the 160th move and the tsuke (Black 2) known as the "Uke no myoshu" made at the 161st move.
Shusai's myoshu (White 1) made at the 160th move and the tsuke (Black 2) known as the "Uke no myoshu" made at the 161st move.

sen.j: 結局この碁は、この妙手が働いて秀哉の2目勝ちに終わった。
sen.e: Eventually, Shusai whose myoshu worked effectively won the game by 2 points.
Eventually, Shusai whose myoshu worked effectively won the game by 2 points.
Eventually, Shusai whose myoshu worked effectively won the game by 2 points.

sen.j: しかし後日、この妙手は秀哉の弟子である前田陳爾が案出した手であるという説が流れており、今もって真相は不明のままとなっている。
sen.e: Later, however, a rumor spread that that myoshu was devised by Shusai's disciple named Nobuaki MAEDA, without revealing the whole truth.
Later, however, a rumor spread that that myoshu was devised by Shusai's disciple named Nobuaki MAEDA, but the whole truth still remains unknown.
sen.cmt: 原文の意味と異なる訳のため修正しました。
sen.e: Later, however, a rumor spread that that myoshu was devised by Shusai's disciple named Nobuaki MAEDA, but the whole truth still remains unknown.

sen.j: 引退碁
sen.e: Retirement Match
Retirement Match
Retirement Match

sen.j: 1938年、64歳の秀哉は現役引退を発表し、リーグ戦を勝ち抜いた木谷實を相手に引退碁を打つこととなった。
sen.e: In 1938, at the age of 64, Shusai announced his retirement as a professional go player, playing a retirement game with Minoru KITANI who had won the victory over the league match.
In 1938, at the age of 64, Shusai announced his retirement as a professional go player, playing a retirement game with Minoru KITANI who had won the victory over the league match.
In 1938, at the age of 64, Shusai announced his retirement as a professional go player, playing a retirement game with Minoru KITANI who had won the victory over the league match.

sen.j: 史上最長となる持ち時間40時間、史上初となる封じ手制で行われ、6月26日に開始された。
sen.e: With the longest allotted time of 40 hours in history and the newly adopted rule to seal the move before each adjournment, the game started on June 26.
With the longest allotted time of 40 hours in history and the newly adopted rule to seal the move before each adjournment, the game started on June 26.
With the longest allotted time of 40 hours in history and the newly adopted rule to seal the move before each adjournment, the game started on June 26.

sen.j: 20回の打ちかけをはさみ、途中秀哉の入院などもあり終局まで打ち通せるか危ぶまれもしたが、12月4日に終局。
sen.e: 20 adjournments were called during the game, and Shusai who was sick and went to hospital in the middle of the game was in danger of giving up, but the game finally reached the end on December 4.
20 adjournments were called during the game, and Shusai who was sick and went to hospital in the middle of the game was in danger of giving up, but the game finally reached the end on December 4.
20 adjournments were called during the game, and Shusai who was sick and went to hospital in the middle of the game was in danger of giving up, but the game finally reached the end on December 4.

sen.j: 結果は木谷の5目勝ちとなった。
sen.e: As a result, Kitani won by 5 points.
As a result, Kitani won by 5 points.
As a result, Kitani won by 5 points.

sen.j: この対局の観戦記を担当した川端康成は後にこれを小説に起こし「名人 (小説)」という名で発表している。
sen.e: Yasunari KAWABATA, who wrote a review of that retirement game, later novelized the game under the title "Meijin" (The Master of Go).
Yasunari KAWABATA, who wrote a review of that retirement game, later novelized the game under the title "Meijin" (The Master of Go).
